elements.content: Uranyl nitrate was reacted with several polycarboxylic acids under solvo-/hydrothermal conditions using N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) as the organic component to give six novel complexes, which were crystallographically characterized. NMP is coordinated to the uranyl ion in all cases but one. The complex with terephthalic acid (H2tph), [UO2(tph)(NMP)] (1), crystallizes as a three-dimensional (3D) framework, an unprecedented feature in uranyl complexes with this ligand. The two complexes obtained with 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (H2thd), [UO2(thd)(NMP)] (2 and 3), crystallize as 3D frameworks having the same formula and topology but different packings. Two complexes were also obtained with 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid (H3bta), [(UO2)3(bta)2(NMP)3]·0.5H2O (4) and [Hbipy][UO2(bta)]·H2O (5). Complex 4, with NMP coordinated, is a 2D assembly, with a sheet thickness of ∼12 Å arising from the superposition of three sublayers. Complex 5, obtained in the presence of 2,2′-bipyridine (bipy), is a 1D polymer with a nanotubular shape subtended by π-stacking interactions. In the additional presence of nickel(II) nitrate, nitrilotriacetic acid (H3nta) gives the complex [(UO2)2Ni(nta)2(NMP)2]·NMP (6), which crystallizes as a 3D framework that, like complexes 1 and 3, displays channels containing coordinated or free NMP molecules. The emission spectra under excitation at 350 nm were measured for all of the complexes. The usual vibronic fine structure in the ∼460–600 nm range is apparent for 1–5, while 6 shows only a weak and featureless band indicative of quenching of the uranyl luminescence by Ni(II). The properties of these complexes illustrate the potential of solvo-/hydrothermal methods, particularly those involving coordinating organic solvents, for the synthesis of new uranyl–organic species.

elements.content: Among the six complexes obtained from reactions of uranyl nitrate with four different di- and tricarboxylic acids under solvo-/hydrothermal conditions involving N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), four crystallize as three-dimensional frameworks including coordinated NMP molecules, while another is a thick, three-decker, two-dimensional assembly and the last is a nanotubular-shaped polymer.
elements.clean_text: Among the six complexes obtained from reactions of uranyl nitrate with four different di- and tricarboxylic acids under solvo-/hydrothermal conditions involving N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), four crystallize as three-dimensional frameworks including coordinated NMP molecules, while another is a thick, three-decker, two-dimensional assembly and the last is a nanotubular-shaped polymer.

elements.content: Uranyl–organic coordination polymers and frameworks (UOFs) are often synthesized under mild hydrothermal conditions, and the oligomeric or polymeric condensation products formed by hydrolysis play an important role as secondary building units in the final structure. The nature of the products formed can be modulated through variations in pH, temperature, or concentration of the reagents, but a rather infrequently used modification of the synthesis conditions that may have important consequences for the issue of the reaction consists of using mixtures of water and organic solvents. Although pure solvothermal conditions (not necessarily strictly anhydrous) seem to have seldom been used in the synthesis of UOFs (e.g., pyridine for the complexes with 1,1-cyclobutanedicarboxylate and camphorate), solvo-/hydrothermal conditions are more frequent. Apart from its usefulness in the case of ligands that are sparingly soluble in water, the organic solvent can assume other functions, for example as an additional coordinating species. While acetonitrile, ethanol or 2-propanol are absent from the final compounds, methanol is both coordinated and present as a lattice solvent molecule in the uranyl complex with camphoric acid prepared in the presence of this solvent. N,N-Dimethylformamide is a special case since, aside from being a coordinating solvent, it readily undergoes hydrolysis to give formate anions and dimethylammonium cations upon heating in at least partly aqueous media in the presence of metal cations, and the species thus generated in situ have proved to be useful as ligands or counterions in uranyl complexes with cucurbit[6]uril. N-Methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), another polar and aprotic coordinating solvent that is also an amide, has not been used until very recently for the synthesis of UOFs, in spite of its much greater hydrolytic stability relative to DMF at the temperatures commonly used. The original results obtained with this solvent in the case of uranyl complexation by Kemp’s triacid (cis,cis-1,3,5-trimethylcyclohexane-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid) prompted us to investigate other polycarboxylic acids under similar solvo-/hydrothermal conditions. The synthesis, crystal structures, and luminescence properties of the uranyl complexes thus obtained with two dicarboxylic acids, terephthalic (1,4-benzenedicarboxylic) acid (H2tph) and 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (H2thd), and with two tricarboxylic acids, 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid (H3bta) and nitrilotriacetic acid (H3nta), are reported herein. Two-dimensional (2D) uranyl–organic assemblies with terephthalate and 1,3,5-benzenetriacetate have previously been reported, as well as 1D ladder- and ribbonlike polymers with terephthalate and nitrilotriacetate, but dinuclear molecular complexes only are known with 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylate (with terpyridine coligands). Although 1D and 2D architectures are most often found in uranyl–organic compounds, it is notable that a 3D framework is obtained with the mononitro derivative of terephthalic acid, a seemingly minor modification (since the nitro group is uncoordinated) having a very important structural effect. Some polycarboxylates display sufficient out-of-the-plane connectivity to overcome the natural propensity of the uranyl ion to organize its ligands within an equatorial plane, giving complexes that crystallize as 3D frameworks. Specific strategies have also been devised for extending the dimensionality of the assemblies formed, such as the use of additional metal cations or of cation–cation interactions between uranyl ions. As exemplified in the present work, coordinating solvents may also have the unexpected effect of promoting 3D architectures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Uranyl-organic coordination polymers and frameworks (UOFs) are often synthesized under mild hydrothermal conditions, and the oligomeric or polymeric condensation products formed by hydrolysis play an important role as secondary building units in the final structure. The nature of the products formed can be modulated through variations in pH, temperature, or concentration of the reagents, but a rather infrequently used modification of the synthesis conditions that may have important consequences for the issue of the reaction consists of using mixtures of water and organic solvents. Although pure solvothermal conditions (not necessarily strictly anhydrous) seem to have seldom been used in the synthesis of UOFs (e.g., pyridine for the complexes with 1,1-cyclobutanedicarboxylate and camphorate), solvo-/hydrothermal conditions are more frequent. Apart from its usefulness in the case of ligands that are sparingly soluble in water, the organic solvent can assume other functions, for example as an additional coordinating species. While acetonitrile, ethanol or 2-propanol are absent from the final compounds, methanol is both coordinated and present as a lattice solvent molecule in the uranyl complex with camphoric acid prepared in the presence of this solvent. N,N-Dimethylformamide is a special case since, aside from being a coordinating solvent, it readily undergoes hydrolysis to give formate anions and dimethylammonium cations upon heating in at least partly aqueous media in the presence of metal cations, and the species thus generated in situ have proved to be useful as ligands or counterions in uranyl complexes with cucurbit[6]uril. N-Methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), another polar and aprotic coordinating solvent that is also an amide, has not been used until very recently for the synthesis of UOFs, in spite of its much greater hydrolytic stability relative to DMF at the temperatures commonly used. The original results obtained with this solvent in the case of uranyl complexation by Kemp's triacid (cis,cis-1,3,5-trimethylcyclohexane-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid) prompted us to investigate other polycarboxylic acids under similar solvo-/hydrothermal conditions. The synthesis, crystal structures, and luminescence properties of the uranyl complexes thus obtained with two dicarboxylic acids, terephthalic (1,4-benzenedicarboxylic) acid (H2tph) and 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (H2thd), and with two tricarboxylic acids, 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid (H3bta) and nitrilotriacetic acid (H3nta), are reported herein. Two-dimensional (2D) uranyl-organic assemblies with terephthalate and 1,3,5-benzenetriacetate have previously been reported, as well as 1D ladder- and ribbonlike polymers with terephthalate and nitrilotriacetate, but dinuclear molecular complexes only are known with 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylate (with terpyridine coligands). Although 1D and 2D architectures are most often found in uranyl-organic compounds, it is notable that a 3D framework is obtained with the mononitro derivative of terephthalic acid, a seemingly minor modification (since the nitro group is uncoordinated) having a very important structural effect. Some polycarboxylates display sufficient out-of-the-plane connectivity to overcome the natural propensity of the uranyl ion to organize its ligands within an equatorial plane, giving complexes that crystallize as 3D frameworks. Specific strategies have also been devised for extending the dimensionality of the assemblies formed, such as the use of additional metal cations or of cation-cation interactions between uranyl ions. As exemplified in the present work, coordinating solvents may also have the unexpected effect of promoting 3D architectures.

elements.content:
Because uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection.

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (depleted uranium, R. P. Normapur, 99%) and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (99%) were purchased from Prolabo. Terephthalic, 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic, and nitrilotriacetic acids were obtained from Aldrich, while 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid was obtained from Fluka and N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone from Carlo Erba. Elemental analyses were performed by MEDAC Ltd. (Chobham, UK).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Syntheses

Because uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection.

UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (depleted uranium, R. P. Normapur, 99%) and Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (99%) were purchased from Prolabo. Terephthalic, 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic, and nitrilotriacetic acids were obtained from Aldrich, while 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid was obtained from Fluka and N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone from Carlo Erba. Elemental analyses were performed by MEDAC Ltd. (Chobham, UK).

elements.content: Terephthalic acid (17 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), NMP (0.5 mL), and demineralized water (1.0 mL) were placed in a tightly closed 15 mL glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure. Light-yellow crystals of complex 1 appeared overnight (42 mg, 79% yield). Anal. Calcd for C13H13NO7U: C, 29.28; H, 2.46; N, 2.63%. Found: C, 29.45; H, 2.63; N, 2.57%.

elements.content: 1,3,5-Benzenetriacetic acid (25 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (25 mg, 0.10 mmol), 2,2′-bipyridine (31 mg, 0.20 mmol), NMP (0.5 mL), and demineralized water (1.0 mL) were placed in a tightly closed 15 mL glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure. Light-yellow crystals of complex 5 appeared overnight (30 mg, 43% yield). Anal. Calcd for C22H20N2O9U + 1.5H2O: C, 36.63; H, 3.21; N, 3.88%. Found: C, 36.81; H, 2.92; N, 3.75%. These analytical results show that the bulk material had a somewhat higher degree of hydration than the single crystal selected for the structure determination, perhaps as a consequence of grinding of the sample under the normal atmosphere prior to the analysis.

elements.content: The data were collected at 150(2) K on a Nonius Kappa CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protective coating of Paratone-N oil (Hampton Research). The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames and then refined on all data. The data [combinations of φ and ω scans giving complete data sets up to θ = 30° (28° for compound 4) with a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections] were processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by direct methods, expanded by subsequent Fourier difference synthesis, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The NMP molecule in compound 1 is disordered over two positions related to one another by the twofold rotation axis containing atom C5; restraints had to be applied on bond lengths and displacement parameters for the atoms in the disordered part as well as on the displacement parameters of the oxo atom O1, which is likely disordered over two positions correlated with the two positions of atom O4 of NMP but not sufficiently distinct to be refined separately. In compound 4, restraints on bond lengths and displacement parameters had to be applied for the three NMP molecules, which are likely affected by unresolved disorder; the lattice water molecule was given an occupancy parameter of 0.5 in order to retain an acceptable displacement factor, and its hydrogen atoms were not found. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen and nitrogen atoms in compound 5 were found on a Fourier difference map. The carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions in all compounds. All hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with isotropic displacement parameters equal to 1.2 times those of the parent atoms (1.5 for CH3).
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The data were collected at 150(2) K on a Nonius Kappa CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protective coating of Paratone-N oil (Hampton Research). The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames and then refined on all data. The data [combinations of φ and ω scans giving complete data sets up to θ = 30° (28° for compound 4) with a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections] were processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by direct methods, expanded by subsequent Fourier difference synthesis, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The NMP molecule in compound 1 is disordered over two positions related to one another by the twofold rotation axis containing atom C5; restraints had to be applied on bond lengths and displacement parameters for the atoms in the disordered part as well as on the displacement parameters of the oxo atom O1, which is likely disordered over two positions correlated with the two positions of atom O4 of NMP but not sufficiently distinct to be refined separately. In compound 4, restraints on bond lengths and displacement parameters had to be applied for the three NMP molecules, which are likely affected by unresolved disorder; the lattice water molecule was given an occupancy parameter of 0.5 in order to retain an acceptable displacement factor, and its hydrogen atoms were not found. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen and nitrogen atoms in compound 5 were found on a Fourier difference map. The carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions in all compounds. All hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with isotropic displacement parameters equal to 1.2 times those of the parent atoms (1.5 for CH3).

Emission spectra were recorded on solid samples using a Horiba Jobin Yvon FluoroLog spectrofluorimeter. Powdered complex was pressed between two silica plates, which were mounted in such a way that the faces were oriented vertically and at 45° to the incident excitation radiation. An excitation wavelength of 350 nm was used in all cases, and the emissions were monitored between 400 and 800 nm; a 400 nm bandpass filter was used to block transmission of the excitation radiation.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Measurements

Emission spectra were recorded on solid samples using a Horiba Jobin Yvon FluoroLog spectrofluorimeter. Powdered complex was pressed between two silica plates, which were mounted in such a way that the faces were oriented vertically and at 45° to the incident excitation radiation. An excitation wavelength of 350 nm was used in all cases, and the emissions were monitored between 400 and 800 nm; a 400 nm bandpass filter was used to block transmission of the excitation radiation.

elements.content: Complexes 1–5 were synthesized under solvo-/hydrothermal conditions at 140 °C with NMP as the organic component. NMP appears to be well-adapted for that and does not undergo the hydrolysis observed with DMF. In all complexes but 5, it is present in the final complex as an additional ligand (and also as a solvent in 6). Curiously, only one example of a crystal structure showing coordination of NMP to the uranyl ion is known, but 20 structures containing other N-alkyl derivatives of 2-pyrrolidone (and the latter itself in one case) are reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, version 5.34), these molecules having been used in particular as selective precipitants for uranyl ions in the context of nuclear fuel reprocessing technology. An interesting feature in the present series of compounds is the complete absence both of coordinated water and of species resulting from uranyl hydrolysis. The latter species, built around oxo or hydroxo bridges, are very frequent in uranyl aqueous chemistry, and since they often give quite compact secondary building units of quasi-planar shape, they are not particularly conducive to the formation of 3D frameworks. Besides the use of low-pH solutions, high-halide media have been proposed as a means of avoiding the formation of highly unpredictable hydrolysis products through the reproducible generation of the synthons [UO2X4]2– (X = Cl, Br); the present results suggest that solvo-/hydrothermal conditions can be, at least in particular cases, an alternative way toward the same end, especially when the solvent itself resists hydrolysis and thus pH changes that may be associated with this reaction. It should be noted that although all of the presently isolated complexes contained the ligands in their carboxylate forms, these ligands were added to the reaction mixtures in their acid forms; thus, the coordination (and crystallization) reactions can be considered as leading to the release of H+. This may explain why when 2,2′-bipyridine was added to some of the reaction mixtures, it was either not present in the isolated complexes or present only in the form of its monoprotonated cation.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Complexes 1-5 were synthesized under solvo-/hydrothermal conditions at 140 °C with NMP as the organic component. NMP appears to be well-adapted for that and does not undergo the hydrolysis observed with DMF. In all complexes but 5, it is present in the final complex as an additional ligand (and also as a solvent in 6). Curiously, only one example of a crystal structure showing coordination of NMP to the uranyl ion is known, but 20 structures containing other N-alkyl derivatives of 2-pyrrolidone (and the latter itself in one case) are reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, version 5.34), these molecules having been used in particular as selective precipitants for uranyl ions in the context of nuclear fuel reprocessing technology. An interesting feature in the present series of compounds is the complete absence both of coordinated water and of species resulting from uranyl hydrolysis. The latter species, built around oxo or hydroxo bridges, are very frequent in uranyl aqueous chemistry, and since they often give quite compact secondary building units of quasi-planar shape, they are not particularly conducive to the formation of 3D frameworks. Besides the use of low-pH solutions, high-halide media have been proposed as a means of avoiding the formation of highly unpredictable hydrolysis products through the reproducible generation of the synthons [UO2X4]2- (X = Cl, Br); the present results suggest that solvo-/hydrothermal conditions can be, at least in particular cases, an alternative way toward the same end, especially when the solvent itself resists hydrolysis and thus pH changes that may be associated with this reaction. It should be noted that although all of the presently isolated complexes contained the ligands in their carboxylate forms, these ligands were added to the reaction mixtures in their acid forms; thus, the coordination (and crystallization) reactions can be considered as leading to the release of H+. This may explain why when 2,2'-bipyridine was added to some of the reaction mixtures, it was either not present in the isolated complexes or present only in the form of its monoprotonated cation.

elements.content: Several uranyl complexes with terephthalic acid that crystallize as either 1D or 2D species have previously been described, but the complex [UO2(tph)(NMP)] (1) is different from all of them. The asymmetric unit in 1 contains half a uranyl ion, with the uranium atom located on a twofold rotation axis (4c site); half a terephthalate ligand, with the other half being generated by the inversion center; and an NMP molecule disordered over two positions sharing the carbon atom of the carbonyl group, which is located on the twofold rotation axis (Figure ). The uranyl ion is bound to four carboxylate oxygen atoms from four different anions and to one NMP molecule, the uranium coordination environment geometry being the usual pentagonal-bipyramidal one. The U–O(NMP) bond length of 2.438(6) Å is longer than that in the other reported NMP complex of the uranyl ion, 2.368(4) Å (although the coordination number in the latter compound is 6). The average U–O(carboxylate) bond length of 2.36(2) Å is unexceptional [the average bond length from the CSD is 2.42(7) Å]. The tph2– anion connects two cations through each of its carboxylate groups, with the C1–O3–U angle having the unremarkable value of 133.6(3)° while the C1–O2–U angle has the much more unusual value of 168.0(4)°, the three atoms being close to a linear arrangement. Such a bis(bridging bidentate) coordination mode has also been observed in other uranyl terephthalate complexes, besides bis-monodentate bonding and bischelation. However, in 1 it gives rise to the formation of a 3D framework of total point (Schläfli) symbol {42.82.102}{42.84} (the first symbol for the tph2– anions and the second for the uranium atoms). When the framework is viewed down the b axis, quadrangular channels with double uranyl rows as vertices are apparent, with a side length of ∼9 Å and a longer diagonal of ∼13 Å. The disordered NMP molecules point toward the centers of the channels along the shorter diagonal, so that no free space is present. In comparison with some of the 2D structures previously reported, in which the uranyl ions are bound only to terephthalate ligands, it appears paradoxical that the addition of a terminal extra ligand in 1 results in a higher dimensionality. However, the synthesis conditions are quite different in all of these cases, with the former ones involving different concentrations and temperatures as well as the basic agent NH3 in one case and generation of the terephthalate ligand in situ from hydrolysis of 1,4-dicyanobenzene in another case. It was neatly shown that for a given set of hydrothermal conditions, aromatic dicarboxylate ligands with an overall para position for the carboxylate groups (terephthalate, 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate, 4,4′-azobenzenedicarboxylate) favor the formation of 2D assemblies while the meta position (in isophthalate) produces a 3D framework. A 3D framework is formed by the uranyl complex with 2-nitroterephthalic acid, but it is very different from that in 1 since it involves cation–cation bridging and thus the formation of uranyl dimers.

Crystal Structures

Several uranyl complexes with terephthalic acid that crystallize as either 1D or 2D species have previously been described, but the complex [UO2(tph)(NMP)] (1) is different from all of them. The uranyl ion is bound to four carboxylate oxygen atoms from four different anions and to one NMP molecule, the uranium coordination environment geometry being the usual pentagonal-bipyramidal one. The U-O(NMP) bond length of 2.438(6) Å is longer than that in the other reported NMP complex of the uranyl ion, 2.368(4) Å (although the coordination number in the latter compound is 6). The average U-O(carboxylate) bond length of 2.36(2) Å is unexceptional [the average bond length from the CSD is 2.42(7) Å]. The tph2- anion connects two cations through each of its carboxylate groups, with the C1-O3-U angle having the unremarkable value of 133.6(3)° while the C1-O2-U angle has the much more unusual value of 168.0(4)°, the three atoms being close to a linear arrangement. Such a bis(bridging bidentate) coordination mode has also been observed in other uranyl terephthalate complexes, besides bis-monodentate bonding and bischelation. However, in 1 it gives rise to the formation of a 3D framework of total point (Schläfli) symbol {42.82.102}{42.84} (the first symbol for the tph2- anions and the second for the uranium atoms). When the framework is viewed down the b axis, quadrangular channels with double uranyl rows as vertices are apparent, with a side length of ~9 Å and a longer diagonal of ~13 Å. The disordered NMP molecules point toward the centers of the channels along the shorter diagonal, so that no free space is present. Only one position of the disordered NMP molecule is represented, and hydrogen atoms have been omitted. Symmetry codes: i = 1/2 – x, −y, z; j = 1/2 – x, y + 1/2, 1/2 – z; k = x, −y – 1/2, 1/2 – z; l = 1/2 – x, y – 1/2, 1/2 – z; m = 1 – x, −y, 1 – z; n = x + 1/2, 1/2 – y, z + 1/2. Middle: View of the 3D framework showing the uranium coordination polyhedra. For clarity, only the average position of the NMP oxygen atom is represented and hydrogen atoms have been omitted. Bottom: Nodal representation of the framework. Yellow, uranium; red, oxygen; blue, centroid of the dicarboxylate ligand; dark red, centroid of NMP.

elements.content: Two complexes with the same overall formula, [UO2(thd)(NMP)] (2 and 3), were obtained with 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid, despite the presence of manganese(II) nitrate and 2,2′-bipyridine in the reaction mixture providing 2, added in the hope of enhancing the dimensionality of the product as a (bipy)Mn2+ derivative. Complexes 2 and 3 crystallize in two different space groups of the orthorhombic system (centrosymmetric Pbcn and chiral P212121, respectively), with the asymmetric unit corresponding to one formula unit in both cases (Figures and ). In both of them, the uranyl ion is bound, in its equatorial plane, to four carboxylate oxygen atoms from four thd2– ligands and to one NMP molecule, with U–O(NMP) bond lengths of 2.379(2) and 2.410(3) Å, which are closer than that in 1 to the previously reported value although still slightly larger. The average U–O(carboxylate) bond lengths of 2.38(2) and 2.39(2) Å are unexceptional. Each thd2– ligand connects four cations in the bis(bridging bidentate) mode already found in 1, with slightly different geometries in 2 and 3. In 2, one of the carboxylate groups is bonded in syn,anti fashion and the other in syn,syn fashion, while both are syn,anti in 3. In both cases, 3D frameworks are built with the same total point symbol, {42.84}. In spite of the topological similarity between the two networks, the packing is somewhat different in the two structures. In 2, only narrow channels of ∼6 Å × 6 Å cross section running along the c axis can be discerned, and they are completely obstructed by the NMP methyl groups pointing inside, whereas larger channels along the a axis are apparent in 3, which have dimensions of ∼9 Å × 6 Å and are occupied by the NMP molecules. Unfortunately, no uranyl complex with thd2– could be obtained under purely hydrothermal conditions for comparison, but as for complex 1, the presence of the terminal NMP ligand does not prevent the formation of a 3D species.

elements.content: 1,3,5-Benzenetriacetate is a ligand uniting a central rigid aromatic platform to three flexible arms bearing the binding groups, with which two uranyl complexes were previously obtained under hydrothermal conditions, [UO2(H2O)5][UO2(bta)]2·5H2O and [NMe4][UO2(bta)]·H2O, both of which crystallize as 2D assemblies with bilayer architectures. Two novel complexes with this ligand were obtained in the presence of NMP, [(UO2)3(bta)2(NMP)3]·0.5H2O (4) and [Hbipy][UO2(bta)]·H2O (5), the latter forming when both manganese(II) nitrate and 2,2′-bipyridine were present in the reaction medium. Complex 4 crystallizes with three independent uranyl ions and two bta3– ligands in the asymmetric unit. Each uranyl ion is chelated by one carboxylate group and bound to two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two more ligands and to one NMP molecule (Figure ). The average U–O(NMP) bond length of 2.337(9) Å and the average U–O(carboxylate) bond lengths of 2.45(3) and 2.35(2) Å for chelating and monodentate bonding, respectively, are unremarkable. While each uranyl ion is bound to three bta3– ligands, the two independent ligands display different coordination schemes, since one is doubly chelating and bridging bidentate and the other is singly chelating and bis(bridging bidentate), the numbers of bound uranyl ions thus being four and five, respectively. All of the bridging bidentate groups are coordinated in the syn,anti fashion. In both molecules, the carboxylate groups that are identically coordinated are located on the same side of the aromatic ring, and the group with a different connection is on the other side. Complex 4 crystallizes as a 2D assembly with layers parallel to (101̅). These layers are very thick (∼12 Å) and encompass three sublayers, the external ones containing atoms U2 and U3 and the central one atom U1, and their symmetry equivalents. Being close to the uranyl equatorial planes, the NMP molecules are located within these sublayers. As shown in Figure , the sublayers containing U2 and U3 display [UO2(bta)]4 rings containing the NMP molecules, with one carboxylate group in each ligand being directed out of the plane so as to connect to atoms of the U1 family in the central sublayer. U1 is bound to two ligands from a sublayer and to the image of one of them through an inversion center, pertaining to the other sublayer. Doubly bridged uranyl dimers are present in all sublayers, containing either U2 and U3 or centrosymmetric U1 pairs. The total point symbol is {4.82}{42.6}2{42.84}{43.62.85} (with successive symbols for U3, U1 and U2, and the two inequivalent bta3– ligands, respectively). In the two previously reported complexes with bta3–, in which all of the carboxylate groups were chelating, the 2D assemblies displayed much simpler topologies with the total point symbols {4.82} and {4.102}, respectively (all nodes equivalent and trigonal). Although both of these assemblies were quite thick (strongly corrugated in one case and containing uranyl ions with their equatorial planes orthogonal to the layer plane in the other), the arrangement in 4 appears to be quite special and can be seen as an intermediate step between two- and three-dimensionality. Two carboxylate groups of the ligands are used to build the external sublayers and one is left to extend the structure in a third direction. However, all of the groups in the latter family are located on the same side of the sublayer, and only a centrosymmetric finite assembly is formed, not a 3D framework.

elements.content: Complex 5 is the only one in the present series in which NMP is completely absent. The asymmetric unit corresponds to one formula unit, and the bonding scheme is that found in the two previously reported complexes with bta3– (Figure ). The uranyl ion is bound to three chelating carboxylate groups from three anions, with an average U–O(carboxylate) bond length of 2.47(4) Å. Two of the methylenecarboxylate arms are directed to the same side of the aromatic ring plane, and the third is very close to this plane, with the COO group orthogonal to it. A 1D assembly parallel to the a axis with the total point symbol {42.6} is formed, all nodes being equivalent and trigonal. When viewed down the chain axis, the polymer assumes the shape of a very narrow tubule, with no significant internal space. The Hbipy+ counterion is hydrogen-bonded to a carboxylate oxygen atom [N1···O8, 2.961(3) Å; N1–H···O8, 162°], and the solvent water molecule is hydrogen-bonded to one carboxylate group and the unprotonated nitrogen atom; all of these hydrogen bonds involve carboxylate groups pertaining to the same polymeric chain. π-Stacking interactions may be present between bta3– ligands facing each other in the tubules [centroid···centroid distance, 3.5163(19) Å; slippage, 0.934 Å] and between Hbipy+ cations associated with different chains [centroid···centroid distance, 3.770(2) Å; dihedral angle, 11.90(16)°]. This structure, together with those previously reported, shows that an obvious role of NMP in 4 is to prevent the usual trischelated, six-coordinate bonding scheme found for bta3– in its other three uranyl complexes and thus to permit a completely different architecture to be built.

elements.content: Nitrilotriacetate is another flexible ligand, with the nitrogen atom being an additional potential bonding site. In [(UO2)(Hnta)(H2O)2], the previously reported uranyl complex with this ligand, obtained either from Na2Hnta at room temperature or from N-(2-acetamido)iminodiacetic acid under hydrothermal conditions, the nitrogen atom is uncoordinated and protonated; this complex crystallizes as a planar, ribbonlike 1D polymer. Unfortunately, attempts at the synthesis of a complex from H3nta under solvo-/hydrothermal conditions with NMP resulted only in the precipitation of amorphous powders. Further addition of nickel(II) nitrate and 2,2′-bipyridine permitted the crystallization of the heterometallic complex [(UO2)2Ni(nta)2(NMP)2]·NMP (6), providing a third distinct case of the consequences of adding a transition-metal ion and 2,2′-bipyridine to compare with those of 2 and 5. The asymmetric unit in 6 corresponds to one formula unit, with the nickel atom occupying two positions located on inversion centers (Figure ). Each uranyl ion is chelated by one carboxylate group and is bound to two more carboxylate oxygen atoms from two different anions and to one NMP molecule, with an average U–O(NMP) bond length of 2.389(14) Å and average U–O(carboxylate) bond lengths of 2.48(4) and 2.314(8) Å for chelating and monodentate bonding, respectively. Each nickel atom is bound to the nitrogen atom and two carboxylate oxygen atoms from each of its two ligands, with the third methylenecarboxylate arm being diverted for uranyl chelation. This is at variance with the bonding scheme found in several lanthanide–d-block metal (CuII, CoIII) heterometallic complexes, in which the latter metal ion is bound to the nitrogen atom and one oxygen atom from each arm of the ligand; however, bonding through the nitrogen atom and two arms has been found in the case of lanthanide–MoIV complexes, the third arm being either uncoordinated or bound to the lanthanide ion. Complex 6 crystallizes as a 3D framework that depends on both cations for its formation (a 2D assembly is generated by uranyl alone, if nickel atoms are disregarded) and has the total point symbol {10}{4.82.103}2{4.82}2 (with successive symbols for Ni2+ ions, nta3– ligands, and uranyl ions, respectively). [UO2(nta)]2 rings are connected to one another by the Ni2+ cations, giving chains running along the [101] axis, which are then linked to one another through monodentate carboxylate bonding to uranyl ions. Channels can be seen running along the a and c axes, with dimensions of ∼5 Å × 5 Å and 6 Å × 4 Å, respectively, that are occupied by the coordinated NMP molecules as in compounds 1 and 3. Narrower channels of ∼5 Å × 3 Å cross section can be seen in the [101] direction, parallel to the 1D subunits, in which the free NMP molecules are located.

elements.content: The emission spectra under excitation at a wavelength of 350 nm were recorded for all of the compounds in the solid state (Figure ). Compounds 1–5 display the usual series of fine-structure bands in the ∼460–600 nm range (green to yellow), with typically six peaks corresponding to the S 11 → S 00 and S 10 → S 0ν (ν = 0–4) electronic transitions. However, the positions and relative intensities of the peaks are variable in the series. The maxima appear at ∼482 (w), 497–499 (s), 519–521 (s), 543–546 (s), 570–572 (m), and ∼599 (w) nm in complexes 1–3; 492 (s), 514 (s), and 541 (m) nm in 4; and ∼466 (m), 482 (s), 502 (s), 523(s), 547 (m), and ∼572 (w) nm in 5. The overall pattern is that usually observed in uranyl complexes. The vibronic splitting energy of the S 10 → S 0ν transitions is in the range 800–839 cm–1, which is smaller than the value of 852 cm–1 in uranyl malonates. The ∼730 cm–1 shift between the peak positions in 1–4 and those in 5 may be at least partly due to the different coordination geometry, since the environment of the uranium atom is pentagonal-bipyramidal in complexes 1–4 and hexagonal-bipyramidal in 5. Indeed, the peak positions in 5 are close to those for other eight-coordinate species. It is also notable that 5 is the only compound in this series in which significant π-stacking interactions are present, a factor that may result in strong charge-transfer-based uranyl emission. In contrast, the uranyl ion luminescence in complex 4 is relatively weak, perhaps because energy transfer from the aromatic absorber to the three inequivalent uranyl centers is inefficient. The emission spectrum for complex 6 shows only a weak and very broad maximum at ∼500 nm with no apparent fine structure. Open-shell metal cations such as Ni2+ are known to be efficient luminescence quenchers by means of energy transfer to the d–d absorption band and nonradiative decay, and examples of this phenomenon in uranyl complexes with Cu(II) have been reported. The absence of strong emission lines in the spectrum of 6 is likely to be ascribed to quenching by Ni(II) cations [although such lines have been observed in a uranyl–Ni(II) complex with phosphonate ligands]. Crystals of compounds 1–6 display a pale-yellow color, consistent with the luminescence in the green being weak and thus making a minor contribution to what is usually perceived visually as a result of the uranyl absorption.

The maxima appear at ~482 (w), 497-499 (s), 519-521 (s), 543-546 (s), 570-572 (m), and ~599 (w) nm in complexes 1-3; 492 (s), 514 (s), and 541 (m) nm in 4; and ~466 (m), 482 (s), 502 (s), 523(s), 547 (m), and ~572 (w) nm in 5. The overall pattern is that usually observed in uranyl complexes. The vibronic splitting energy of the S 10 → S 0ν transitions is in the range 800-839 cm-1, which is smaller than the value of 852 cm-1 in uranyl malonates. The ~730 cm-1 shift between the peak positions in 1-4 and those in 5 may be at least partly due to the different coordination geometry, since the environment of the uranium atom is pentagonal-bipyramidal in complexes 1-4 and hexagonal-bipyramidal in 5. Indeed, the peak positions in 5 are close to those for other eight-coordinate species. It is also notable that 5 is the only compound in this series in which significant π-stacking interactions are present, a factor that may result in strong charge-transfer-based uranyl emission. In contrast, the uranyl ion luminescence in complex 4 is relatively weak, perhaps because energy transfer from the aromatic absorber to the three inequivalent uranyl centers is inefficient. The emission spectrum for complex 6 shows only a weak and very broad maximum at ~500 nm with no apparent fine structure. Open-shell metal cations such as Ni2+ are known to be efficient luminescence quenchers by means of energy transfer to the d-d absorption band and nonradiative decay, and examples of this phenomenon in uranyl complexes with Cu(II) have been reported. The absence of strong emission lines in the spectrum of 6 is likely to be ascribed to quenching by Ni(II) cations [although such lines have been observed in a uranyl-Ni(II) complex with phosphonate ligands]. Crystals of compounds 1-6 display a pale-yellow color, consistent with the luminescence in the green being weak and thus making a minor contribution to what is usually perceived visually as a result of the uranyl absorption.

elements.content: In succession to a study of the uranyl ion complexes of Kemp’s triacid, the present results offer further elaboration of the effect of the coordinating solvent NMP in the solvo-/hydrothermal synthesis of uranyl–organic coordination polymers and frameworks. NMP is coordinated in all of the complexes in this study except for 5, and as previously noted, there is a broad tendency for the shortest U–O(NMP) bonds to be associated with the largest U–O–C angles, the latter being in the 136–148° range. While solvent coordination could be intuitively considered to be detrimental to the formation of high-dimensional species, the structure of complex 1, with terephthalate ligands, displays the unexpected feature of 3D framework formation, a unique case with this ligand. 3D frameworks are also obtained with 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylate in complexes 2 and 3. Depending on the experimental conditions, 1,3,5-benzenetriacetate gives either a 2D assembly containing coordinated NMP molecules (4) or a 1D polymer devoid of NMP (5), which has a bonding scheme closer to those in the previously reported complexes with this tricarboxylate ligand. Where NMP is not found in the isolated solids, it is possible that it still plays an important role in that its hydrolytic stability means that reaction mixtures retain their acidic nature. Complex 4 displays a very original and intricate structure in which the thick sheets are built from three distinct sublayers, thus exhibiting a partial but substantial extension in the third direction. Finally, the uranyl–nickel(II) heterometallic complex 6 with nitrilotriacetate and NMP ligands pertains to the growing category of 3D uranyl–organic frameworks incorporating additional cations. A noticeable structural feature in the 3D compounds 1, 3, and 6 is the presence of channels containing coordinated or free NMP molecules; although this may be indicative of some structure-directing role exerted by NMP, it is also unfortunate in that none of the present species displays significant porosity. In future work, the structural effects of other coordinating solvents could be compared with those of NMP; dimethylacetamide, for example, is a suitable candidate and has previously been shown to exert an influence on the geometry of lead(II)–organic coordination polymers. Complexes 1–5 are luminescent under excitation at 350 nm. The luminescence is particularly strong in complexes 1, 3, and 5, and in all cases it displays vibronic fine structure with up to six emission bands. In contrast, complex 6 displays only a featureless weak band, probably as a consequence of quenching of the uranyl ion excited state by the Ni(II) center. Following earlier results obtained with other solvents such as acetonitrile or DMF, this work illustrates the potential of solvo-/hydrothermal methods for the synthesis of novel, and sometimes very original, uranyl–organic assemblies. A minor but interesting feature of the present results is that the addition to the reaction mixtures of species such as M(II) cations and 2,2′-bipyridine, intended to control the degree of solid-state aggregation, can have rather different consequences depending upon the particular system.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In succession to a study of the uranyl ion complexes of Kemp's triacid, the present results offer further elaboration of the effect of the coordinating solvent NMP in the solvo-/hydrothermal synthesis of uranyl-organic coordination polymers and frameworks. NMP is coordinated in all of the complexes in this study except for 5, and as previously noted, there is a broad tendency for the shortest U-O(NMP) bonds to be associated with the largest U-O-C angles, the latter being in the 136-148° range. While solvent coordination could be intuitively considered to be detrimental to the formation of high-dimensional species, the structure of complex 1, with terephthalate ligands, displays the unexpected feature of 3D framework formation, a unique case with this ligand. 3D frameworks are also obtained with 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylate in complexes 2 and 3. Depending on the experimental conditions, 1,3,5-benzenetriacetate gives either a 2D assembly containing coordinated NMP molecules (4) or a 1D polymer devoid of NMP (5), which has a bonding scheme closer to those in the previously reported complexes with this tricarboxylate ligand. Where NMP is not found in the isolated solids, it is possible that it still plays an important role in that its hydrolytic stability means that reaction mixtures retain their acidic nature. Complex 4 displays a very original and intricate structure in which the thick sheets are built from three distinct sublayers, thus exhibiting a partial but substantial extension in the third direction. Finally, the uranyl-nickel(II) heterometallic complex 6 with nitrilotriacetate and NMP ligands pertains to the growing category of 3D uranyl-organic frameworks incorporating additional cations. A noticeable structural feature in the 3D compounds 1, 3, and 6 is the presence of channels containing coordinated or free NMP molecules; although this may be indicative of some structure-directing role exerted by NMP, it is also unfortunate in that none of the present species displays significant porosity. In future work, the structural effects of other coordinating solvents could be compared with those of NMP; dimethylacetamide, for example, is a suitable candidate and has previously been shown to exert an influence on the geometry of lead(II)-organic coordination polymers. Complexes 1-5 are luminescent under excitation at 350 nm. The luminescence is particularly strong in complexes 1, 3, and 5, and in all cases it displays vibronic fine structure with up to six emission bands. In contrast, complex 6 displays only a featureless weak band, probably as a consequence of quenching of the uranyl ion excited state by the Ni(II) center. Following earlier results obtained with other solvents such as acetonitrile or DMF, this work illustrates the potential of solvo-/hydrothermal methods for the synthesis of novel, and sometimes very original, uranyl-organic assemblies. A minor but interesting feature of the present results is that the addition to the reaction mixtures of species such as M(II) cations and 2,2'-bipyridine, intended to control the degree of solid-state aggregation, can have rather different consequences depending upon the particular system.

Terephthalic acid (17 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), NMP (0.5 mL), and demineralized water (1.0 mL) were placed in a tightly closed 15 mL glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure. Light-yellow crystals of complex 1 appeared overnight (42 mg, 79% yield). Anal. Calcd for C13H13NO7U: C, 29.28; H, 2.46; N, 2.63%. Found: C, 29.45; H, 2.63; N, 2.57%.

[UO<sub>2</sub>(thd)(NMP)] (<bold>2</bold>)

2,5-Thiophenedicarboxylic acid (17 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (25 mg, 0.10 mmol), 2,2′-bipyridine (31 mg, 0.20 mmol), NMP (0.5 mL), and demineralized water (1.0 mL) were placed in a tightly closed 15 mL glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure. Light-yellow crystals of complex 2 appeared overnight (26 mg, 48% yield). Anal. Calcd for C11H11NO7SU: C, 24.50; H, 2.06; N, 2.60; S, 5.95%. Found: C, 24.68; H, 2.77; N, 2.58; S, 6.03%.

[UO<sub>2</sub>(thd)(NMP)] (<bold>3</bold>)

2,5-Thiophenedicarboxylic acid (17 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), NMP (0.5 mL), and demineralized water (1.0 mL) were placed in a tightly closed 15 mL glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure for 1 month. Light-yellow crystals of complex 3 appeared upon subsequent cooling (30 mg, 56% yield). Anal. Calcd for C11H11NO7SU: C, 24.50; H, 2.06; N, 2.60; S, 5.95%. Found: C, 24.66; H, 2.22; N, 2.72; S, 5.77%.

[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>3</sub>(bta)<sub>2</sub>(NMP)<sub>3</sub>]·0.5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

1,3,5-Benzenetriacetic acid (25 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), NMP (0.5 mL), and demineralized water (1.0 mL) were placed in a tightly closed 15 mL glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure. Light-yellow crystals of complex 4 appeared within 4 days (36 mg, 67% yield based on U). Anal. Calcd for C39H46N3O21.5U3: C, 29.01; H, 2.87; N, 2.60%. Found: C, 28.91; H, 2.84; N, 2.56%.

[Hbipy][UO<sub>2</sub>(bta)]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>5</bold>)

1,3,5-Benzenetriacetic acid (25 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (25 mg, 0.10 mmol), 2,2′-bipyridine (31 mg, 0.20 mmol), NMP (0.5 mL), and demineralized water (1.0 mL) were placed in a tightly closed 15 mL glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure. Light-yellow crystals of complex 5 appeared overnight (30 mg, 43% yield). Anal. Calcd for C22H20N2O9U + 1.5H2O: C, 36.63; H, 3.21; N, 3.88%. Found: C, 36.81; H, 2.92; N, 3.75%. These analytical results show that the bulk material had a somewhat higher degree of hydration than the single crystal selected for the structure determination, perhaps as a consequence of grinding of the sample under the normal atmosphere prior to the analysis.

[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Ni(nta)<sub>2</sub>(NMP)<sub>2</sub>]·NMP (<bold>6</bold>)

Nitrilotriacetic acid (19 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (29 mg, 0.10 mmol), 2,2′-bipyridine (16 mg, 0.10 mmol), NMP (0.5 mL), and demineralized water (1.0 mL) were placed in a tightly closed 15 mL glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure. Light-yellow-green crystals of complex 6 appeared overnight (32 mg, 50% yield based on U). Anal. Calcd for C27H39N5NiO19U2: C, 25.49; H, 3.09; N, 5.50%. Found: C, 25.22; H, 3.06; N, 5.39%.

cln_elements.content: Top: View of complex 1. Displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 50% probability level. Only one position of the disordered NMP molecule is represented, and hydrogen atoms have been omitted. Symmetry codes: i = 1/2 – x, −y, z; j = 1/2 – x, y + 1/2, 1/2 – z; k = x, −y – 1/2, 1/2 – z; l = 1/2 – x, y – 1/2, 1/2 – z; m = 1 – x, −y, 1 – z; n = x + 1/2, 1/2 – y, z + 1/2. Middle: View of the 3D framework showing the uranium coordination polyhedra. For clarity, only the average position of the NMP oxygen atom is represented and hydrogen atoms have been omitted. Bottom: Nodal representation of the framework. Yellow, uranium; red, oxygen; blue, centroid of the dicarboxylate ligand; dark red, centroid of NMP.
